description: Crystal Graziano I've always wondered why the shortest day of the year is considered the START of winter and not the MIDDLE of winter. This article doesn't answer that, but it does shed light on the meteorological seasons which make more sense to me!

comments.content: I suppose which one is preferable depends on your profession or your  hobbies.  I would argue that astronomical seasons are less arbitrary than meteorological ones -- depending on one's location, June, July, and August may not make sense as a grouping for similar temperatures or meteorological phenomenon -- e.g. what if one lived in India, near the equator?  Then it might be a difference of dry vs. wet?

description: Crystal Graziano I find myself replacing the word "data" with the word "cats" in my head to say the correct verb that follows. Why? Everyone around me talks as if "data" is/are plural, while I can't help but use "data" as if it/they were grammatically a singular mass noun (like "peanut butter"), thus I don't want to look/sound like an idiot to these people. I try my darnedest to conform, hence cats. I say I'm a data analyst when people ask me what I do, but really I mean I'm a cats analyst.  All that being said, I still refuse to conform to the archaic use of two spaces after a period. The cats show that one space is better than two. Nellie

Megan Talbot  is with  Crystal Graziano  and  29 others . Here's my 27th year of life!  Crammed into four minutes.   A lot can happen in 365 days. So many laughs, so many adventures, so many reunions. But lots of heartbreak, loss, and mourning too.   There were a few big events. But the small and seemingly insignificant moments make the biggest impact. .  To the people who do the best job of caring about me: thank you dearly for making each year worth the time.
